revisions.*: Because "rvslots" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used.

{{stack begin}} {{Taxobox | image = Lactarius glyciosmus 20121201w.JPG | image_width = 234px | regnum = [[Fungus|Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Russulales]] | familia = [[Russulaceae]] | genus = ''[[Lactarius]]'' | species = '''''L. glyciosmus''''' | binomial = ''Lactarius glyciosmus'' | binomial_authority = ([[Elias Magnus Fries|Fr.]] ex Fr.) Fr. (1838) | synonyms_ref = {{cite web |title=''Lactarius glyciosmus'' (Fr.) Fr. 1838 |url=http://www.mycobank.org/MycoTaxo.aspx?Link=T&Rec=120552 |publisher=International Mycological Association |work=MycoBank |accessdate=2011-06-06}} | synonyms = ''Agaricus glyciosmus'' Fr. (1818)
''Galorrheus glyciosmus'' (Fr.) P.Kumm. (1871)
''Lactifluus glyciosmus'' (Fr.) Kuntze (1891) }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Lactarius glyciosmus'' | whichGills = decurrent | capShape = convex | hymeniumType= gills | stipeCharacter= bare | ecologicalType= mycorrhizal | sporePrintColor= cream | howEdible= edible }} {{stack end}} '''''Lactarius glyciosmus''''' (commonly known as the '''coconut scented milk cap''') is a semi-edible mushroom in the genus ''[[Lactarius]]''. [[Mycorrhizal]], it can be found growing in soil at the base of birch trees in Europe. It is typically coloured a greyish lilac, with the sometimes hollow [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] a little lighter coloured than the [[pileus (mycology)|cap]]. It has crowded, decurrent gills, and smells strongly of [[coconut]]s. ==Taxonomy== ''Lactarius glyciosmus'' was initially described by the Swedish [[mycologist]] [[Elias Magnus Fries]] as ''Agaricus glyciosmus'' in 1818. Its [[specific name (botany)|specific name]] is derived from the [[Ancient Greek]] words ''glukos'' "sugar(y)", and ''osmos'' "smell". ==Description== [[File:2009-08-16 Lactarius glyciosmus (Fr.) Fr 53964.jpg|left|thumb]] ''L. glyciosmus'' is a small to medium-sized [[agaric]],{{cite book |title= The Encyclopedia of Fungi of Britain and Europe|last= Jordan|first= Michael|year= 2004|publisher= [[Frances Lincoln]]|isbn= 978-0-7112-2379-0|page= 304|url= https://books.google.com/?id=bFMfytLn3bEC&pg=PA304&dq=%22Lactarius+glyciosmus%22}} which typically has a convex [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] measuring between 2 and 5.5 centimetres, with a small central depression developing with age. Sometimes there is a central pimple, and the cap is typically coloured a greyish lilac, sometimes varying to a pale buff. It is thin fleshed, with an incurved margin in younger specimens. The [[Stipe (mycology)|stem]] measures between 25 and 65 millimetres in height, with a width between 4 and 12 millimetres. The cylindrical stem is typically widest at the bottom becoming narrower towards the top, or sometimes club shaped. The stem is concolorous with the cap, but sometimes is a little paler or with a yellowish hue. The stem is particularly soft and easily broken, and can become hollow. The flesh is buff. The gills are decurrent and crowded, and vary in colour from a pale yellowish to a pale flesh, turning to a greyish lilac with age. The [[latex|milk]] is white with an initially mild, later hot and acrid taste.{{cite book |title= Mushrooms and other fungi of Britain and Europe|last= Phillips|first= Roger|year= 1981|publisher= [[Pan Books]]|isbn= 0-330-26441-9|page= 85}} The mushroom has a strong smell of [[coconut]]s. It is similar to ''[[Lactarius vietus|L. vietus]]'', the grey milk cap, but is differentiated by the fact ''L. vietus'' milk dries grey, while ''L. glyciosmus'' milk dries white. It can also be confused with ''[[Lactarius cocosiolens|L. cocosiolens]]'', which also smells of coconuts, but ''L. cocosiolens'' has a slimy brown or orange cap and is not found among birch.{{Cite web |url= http://www.mushroomexpert.com/lactarius_glyciosmus.html|title= Lactarius glyciosmus|accessdate=14 January 2009 |last= Kuo|first= Michael|publisher= MushroomExpert.com}} The spore print is a creamy white colour, and the spores themselves are broadly elliptic in shape, and covered with small warts. The warts are connected by thin ridges in an incomplete network. The spores measure between 8 and 9 by between 5 and 6 [[micrometre]]s.{{cite book |title= Mushrooms and Toadstools|last= Pegler|first= David M.|year= 1983|publisher= Mitchell Beazley|isbn= 978-0-85533-500-7|page= 98}} ==Natural products== [[File:Sesquiterpene of Lactarius glyciosmus.svg|thumb|left|Sesquiterpenes isolated from ''Lactarius glyciosmus''.|alt=Six chemical structure formulae, each having a six-atom carbon ring in the middle.]] Different compounds, including several [[sesquiterpenes]], have been isolated from ''L. glyciosmus''.{{cite book |author= Vitari G, Vita-Finzi P. |chapter= Sesquiterpenes and other secondary metabolites of genus ''Lactarius'' (Basidiomycetes): Chemistry and biological activity |title=Studies in Natural Products Chemistry. Structure and Chemistry (Part D) |volume=17 |year=1995 |publisher=Elsevier Science |pages=153 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=V8fxtos5C5UC&pg=PA153 |isbn=978-0-08-054198-3}} ==Edibility== ''L. glyciosmus'' is considered edible, but is not recommended to the extent that some mycologists consider it inedible. This species is sold in rural markets in [[Yunnan Province]], China. ==Distribution and habitat== ''L. glyciosmus'' is a common mushroom and is found under broad leaved trees, particularly birch. It can be found between late summer and autumn. It grows in soil individually or in scattered groups. It can be found in North America and Europe,{{Cite web |url= http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~6233.asp|title= Lactarius glyciosmus|accessdate=14 January 2009 |last= Phillips|first= Roger|publisher= RogersMushrooms}} New Zealand,McNab, RFR. (1971). "The Russulaceae of New Zealand Part I. ''Lactarius''". ''New Zealand Journal of Botany'' '''9'''(1): 46-66. [[Svalbard]],Ohenoja E. (1971). The larger fungi of Svalbard and their ecology. ''Annales Universitatis Turkuensis Series A II Biologica-Geographica-Geologica'' '''47''': 122-147. Japan,Murata, Y. (1978). "New records of gill fungi from Hokkaido Japan Part 2". ''Nippon Kingakukai Kaiho'' '''19'''(3): 249-254. and China.Wang, X-H. (2000). "A taxonomic study on some commercial species in the genus ''Lactarius'' (Agaricales) from Yunnan Province, China". ''Acta Botanica Yunnanica'' '''22'''(4): 419-427. ==See also== {{Portal|Fungi}} *[[List of Lactarius species|List of ''Lactarius'' species]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q650468}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lactarius glyciosmus}} [[Category:Lactarius|glyciosmus]] [[Category:Edible fungi]] [[Category:Fungi described in 1818]] [[Category:Fungi of Europe]] [[Category:Fungi of North America]] [[Category:Fungi of Asia]] [[Category:Fungi of New Zealand]] [[Category:Taxa named by Elias Magnus Fries]]
